item.title: Week 8 - Correlation and Regression
item.description: Scatter plot again # load data mydata <- read.csv("https://raw.githubusercontent.com/issactoast/EnBlog/master/static/files/stat2010/examscore.csv", header = TRUE) # clean data; choose 1~5 columns as data set mydata <- mydata[,1:5] # check the result head(mydata) ## class std_id midterm1 midterm2 final ## 1 1 1 70 51 67 ## 2 1 2 78 66 66 ## 3 1 3 80 71 67 ## 4 1 4 75 67 70 ## 5 1 5 73 56 81 ## 6 1 6 89 60 69 Let us draw the scatter plots for the midterm1 vs.

item.title: Week 7 - Correlation
item.description: Excel file to understand the regression line In this discussion section, we will learn how the regression line is determined using the following excel file. leastsquare.xlsx Return to the course page

item.title: Week 7 - Normal distribution 2
item.description: SAT. and ACT. Scores (Standardization) Let us assume you are working at the U of Iowa addmistration department. Every spring semester, you have many application from many future hawk eyes. Today, you have to pick one person to give an admission and you have these infomation about test score of three students; Issac : SAT score - 1250 JAMES : SAT score - 1300 ROBERT: ACT score - 30

item.title: Week 5 - Normal distribution 1
Week 4 - Write your own function and Data manipulation
Week 3 - Data visualization 2
item.description: Data loading again # load data mydata <- read.csv("https://raw.githubusercontent.com/issactoast/EnBlog/master/static/files/stat2010/examscore.csv", header = TRUE) # clean data; choose 1~5 columns as data set mydata <- mydata[,1:5] # check the result head(mydata) ## class std_id midterm1 midterm2 final ## 1 1 1 70 51 67 ## 2 1 2 78 66 66 ## 3 1 3 80 71 67 ## 4 1 4 75 67 70 ## 5 1 5 73 56 81 ## 6 1 6 89 60 69 If you success to load R file, you can see the above results.

item.title: Week 2 - Data visualization
item.description: Data loading again mydata <- read.csv("https://raw.githubusercontent.com/issactoast/EnBlog/master/static/files/stat2010/examscore.csv", header = TRUE) head(mydata) ## class std_id midterm1 midterm2 final X X.1 ## 1 1 1 70 51 67 NA 1 ## 2 1 2 78 66 66 NA NA ## 3 1 3 80 71 67 NA NA ## 4 1 4 75 67 70 NA NA ## 5 1 5 73 56 81 NA NA ## 6 1 6 89 60 69 NA NA If you success to load R file, you can see the above results.

item.title: Week 1 - R Basics and Data loading
item.description: Basic R code and Data loading Today we will learn about the basic R codes and how to load data file to R. R Basics R can be your fancy calculator. 2 + 1 3 - 2 2 * 3 4 / 2 4^2 sqrt(4) # 4^0.5 9 %% 4 # mod 9 %/% 4 # value We can assign value to a variable using <-. a <- 4 a b <- 2 b b <- 3 b a+b Variable contains not only a number but also many things.

item.title: Statistical Methods and Computing (STAT:2010 or 4200)
item.description: Welcome to my discussion section for STAT:2010 and STAT:4200. Issac (Sak) Lee Office location: 213 SH Office hour: Friday 2pm - 5pm Email: sak-lee@uiowa.edu Please put a tag STAT:2010 or STAT:4200 in front of your title when you email me. Course materials Week 0: Access to the virtual desktop Week 1: Basic R and data loading Week 2: Data visualization Week 3: Data visualization 2 (in progress)

item.title: Week 0: Preparation
item.description: Access to the virtual desktop To access the software R and SAS, we can use virtual desktop which the University of Iowa provide students for free. You can think virtual desktop as remote computer which you can log-in through the website. Click the link below. U of Iowa virtual desktop If you are first time to use this website, you need to download the Citrix Workspace App and install it.
